p.The Bachelor of Arts in Interdisciplinar: The Bachelor of Arts in Interdisciplinary Studies – Diversity Studies Track is a broadly based interdisciplinary curriculum. The degree's interdisciplinary nature provides students with tools that can be applied across a spectrum of science, social behavior, and humanities, while foregrounding the importance of analyses with a focus on diversity and inclusion in such categories as race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, religion, and ability. Students pursuing a career in social justice or advocacy work, involvement in international nonprofit organizations or diverse research and journalistic careers, as well as those seeking preparation for graduate study in related areas will enjoy the flexibility of this program. This track requires students to take two unique IDS Core courses, 30 credit hours of courses related to theory and representations/experiences of diversity, and select from a number of related minors such as the Women's and Gender Studies or Diversity and Social Inequality. Students interested in pursuing this B.A. degree should contact the IDS Advising team at is@ucf.edu or 407-823-0144.
p.Interdisciplinary Studies (BA) - Diversi: Interdisciplinary Studies (BA) - Diversity Studies may be completed fully online, although not all elective options or program prerequisites may be offered online. Newly admitted students choosing to complete this program exclusively via UCF online classes may enroll with a reduction in campus-based fees. Click here for more information about the online program.

li.Students who change degree programs and: Students who change degree programs and select this major must adopt the most current catalog.
li.Students must have declared an Interdisc: Students must have declared an Interdisciplinary Studies major - Diversity Studies Track at least two semesters before graduation.
li.Research, Internship, and Independent st: Research, Internship, and Independent study credit may be used in this major with prior approval from Interdisciplinary Studies director. Meet with an Interdisciplinary Studies advisor for additional information.
li.Students must earn at least a \"C\" (2.0: Students must earn at least a "C" (2.0) in each core and restricted elective course.
li.Students must consult with an Interdisci: Students must consult with an Interdisciplinary Studies adviser when entering the degree program and regularly thereafter.
li.Courses designated in 1. (General Educat: Courses designated in 1. (General Education Program) and 2. (Common Program Prerequisites) are usually completed in the first 60 hours.
li.Students wishing to earn an Interdiscipl: Students wishing to earn an Interdisciplinary Studies degree as a double degree, double major, or second degree, must complete all fifty-four credits exclusive of credits done for the other degree(s) and/or major(s), including any minors associated with that degree.

courseSection0.text:
The Bachelor of Arts in Interdisciplinary Studies – Diversity Studies Track is a broadly based interdisciplinary curriculum. The degree's interdisciplinary nature provides students with tools that can be applied across a spectrum of science, social behavior, and humanities, while foregrounding the importance of analyses with a focus on diversity and inclusion in such categories as race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, religion, and ability. Students pursuing a career in social justice or advocacy work, involvement in international nonprofit organizations or diverse research and journalistic careers, as well as those seeking preparation for graduate study in related areas will enjoy the flexibility of this program. This track requires students to take two unique IDS Core courses, 30 credit hours of courses related to theory and representations/experiences of diversity, and select from a number of related minors such as the Women's and Gender Studies or Diversity and Social Inequality. Students interested in pursuing this B.A. degree should contact the IDS Advising team at is@ucf.edu or 407-823-0144.

Interdisciplinary Studies (BA) - Diversity Studies may be completed fully online, although not all elective options or program prerequisites may be offered online. Newly admitted students choosing to complete this program exclusively via UCF online classes may enroll with a reduction in campus-based fees. Click here for more information about the online program.

Degree Requirements
Students who change degree programs and select this major must adopt the most current catalog.
Students must have declared an Interdisciplinary Studies major - Diversity Studies Track at least two semesters before graduation.
Research, Internship, and Independent study credit may be used in this major with prior approval from Interdisciplinary Studies director. Meet with an Interdisciplinary Studies advisor for additional information.
Students must earn at least a "C" (2.0) in each core and restricted elective course.
Students must consult with an Interdisciplinary Studies adviser when entering the degree program and regularly thereafter.
Courses designated in 1. (General Education Program) and 2. (Common Program Prerequisites) are usually completed in the first 60 hours.
Students wishing to earn an Interdisciplinary Studies degree as a double degree, double major, or second degree, must complete all fifty-four credits exclusive of credits done for the other degree(s) and/or major(s), including any minors associated with that degree.

courseSection2.text0: Select primarily from upper level courses, with Interdisciplinary Studies advisor's approval to reach 120 total credit hours.

p.A grade of \"C\" or above (2.0) is requi: A grade of "C" or above (2.0) is required for each course taken in the core and each of the subject areas.
p.Computer Competency is met by department: Computer Competency is met by departmental assessment, or the following courses:

li.Proficiency equivalent to one year of co: Proficiency equivalent to one year of college instruction in either a foreign language or proficiency equivalent to American Sign Language III. Standardized examinations may be used to meet the requirement.
li.Note: Students entering without having m: Note: Students entering without having met the admission requirement must do so in order to graduate.
li.CGS 1060C - Introduction to Computers Cr: CGS 1060C - Introduction to Computers Credit Hours: 3
li.STA 1063C - Basic Statistics Using Micro: STA 1063C - Basic Statistics Using Microsoft Excel Credit Hours: 3
li.42 semester hours of upper division cred: 42 semester hours of upper division credit completed
li.60 semester hours earned after CLEP awar: 60 semester hours earned after CLEP awarded
li.30 of the last 39 hours of course work m: 30 of the last 39 hours of course work must be completed in residency at UCF.
li.A maximum of 45 hours of extension, corr: A maximum of 45 hours of extension, correspondence, CLEP, Credit by Exam, and Armed Forces credits permitted.
li.Complete the General Education Program,: Complete the General Education Program, the Gordon Rule, and nine hours of Summer credit.
li.The Interdisciplinary Studies will maint: The Interdisciplinary Studies will maintain an internal "specialization" list for advising that groups the classes by topic (i.e. race, gender, region of study, etc.).
li.Lower division courses do not substitute: Lower division courses do not substitute for upper division courses.
li.Transfer courses must be evaluated for e: Transfer courses must be evaluated for equivalency credit and/or for use in the degree program by the Interdisciplinary Studies Advising Team. The student must provide all supporting information.
li.Program Academic Learning Compacts (stud: Program Academic Learning Compacts (student learning outcomes) for undergraduate programs are located at: http://www.oeas.ucf.edu/alc/academic_learning_compacts.htm

courseSection0.text:
Foreign Language Requirements

Admissions
Met by graduation requirement
Graduation
Proficiency equivalent to one year of college instruction in either a foreign language or proficiency equivalent to American Sign Language III. Standardized examinations may be used to meet the requirement.
Note: Students entering without having met the admission requirement must do so in order to graduate.

courseSection2.text:

Available Minors, students will choose 1
American Indian Studies
Anthropology in Multicultural Studies
Cultural Anthropology
Diversity and Social Inequality
International and Global Studies
Global Sociology
Mass Culture and Collective Behavior
Humanities and Cultural Studies
Judaic Studies

Religion and Cultural Studies
Africana Studies
American Studies
Asian Studies
Global Peace and Security Studies
Latin American Area Studies
Women's and Gender Studies
World Comparative Studies

courseSection3.text:
Departmental Exit Requirements

A grade of "C" or above (2.0) is required for each course taken in the core and each of the subject areas.
Computer Competency is met by departmental assessment, or the following courses:

CGS 1060C - Introduction to Computers Credit Hours: 3
STA 1063C - Basic Statistics Using Microsoft Excel Credit Hours: 3

University Minimum Exit Requirements

A 2.0 UCF GPA
42 semester hours of upper division credit completed
60 semester hours earned after CLEP awarded
30 of the last 39 hours of course work must be completed in residency at UCF.
A maximum of 45 hours of extension, correspondence, CLEP, Credit by Exam, and Armed Forces credits permitted.
Complete the General Education Program, the Gordon Rule, and nine hours of Summer credit.

courseSection5.text:
Additional Information

Honors In Major
None
Related Programs
Interdisciplinary Studies (B.A./B.S.)
Women's and Gender Studies
Certificates
None
Related Minors
Most UCF minors
Advising Notes
The Interdisciplinary Studies will maintain an internal "specialization" list for advising that groups the classes by topic (i.e. race, gender, region of study, etc.).
Transfer Notes
Lower division courses do not substitute for upper division courses.
Transfer courses must be evaluated for equivalency credit and/or for use in the degree program by the Interdisciplinary Studies Advising Team. The student must provide all supporting information.
Acceptable Substitutes for Transfer Courses
None
Program Academic Learning Compacts
Program Academic Learning Compacts (student learning outcomes) for undergraduate programs are located at: http://www.oeas.ucf.edu/alc/academic_learning_compacts.htm
